user.biography:
Megan {dietitian} & Judy {OT feeding therapist}
📱Online courses 
👶 Babies: Infant Self-Feeding
👧 Toddlers/kids: Prevent/manage picky eating

node.text:
Dr. Jazmine McCoy of @themompsychologist offers tangible tips for parents of young children who want to actively raise them to be anti-racist. Check out more resources at @themompsychologist and on her YouTube channel! Thank you Dr. Jazmine for your willingness to partner with us to offer extremely valuable education on this important topic ❤️❤️❤️
•
Don’t forget to tag a parent who is learning, growing and aiming to put in the work to change the future for all our children.
•
Our 100% fundraiser sale on our online courses ends tonight {Saturday} at 11:59 PM EST. All sales made since we launched this sale Thursday night will benefit @appetiteforchange. Please head back one slide for more info.
•
We will resume feeding content on Sunday. Later today in our stories we will share how we hope to continue to actively evolve as a company and as individuals in working toward anti-racism.

node.title: Raising Anti-Racist Children: Starting the Conversation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Feeding Littles on September 14, 2021 tagging @numnuminc. May be an image of food and text that says 'Serve avocadoto babies Some skin on Crinkle cut Add a coating Leave some skin on the Use crinkle cutter add Lightly coat with fine bottom half for better grip texture to avocado wedges nutritional yeast, bread crumbs, crushed O's cereal Salmon salad Mash and mix with wild boneless salmon (or shredded chicken, hard boiled egg. tuna etc) Avocado toast Smash or serve as slices on toasted bread watch for large seeds and honey in the bread! Mix with quinoa Mash and mix with quinoa {or other small whole grain couscous. rice, bulgur} 909 feedinglittles'.

node.text:
Let’s talk serving avocado 🥑 to babies 6+ months! Will you tag a friend with a baby at home?
•
In our online Infant Course we talk about self-feeding and how to encourage baby to feed themselves with foods they can pick up and bring to their own mouth. This helps promote independence at mealtime and builds important motor skills...but how can babies pick up food when they don’t yet have a pincer grasp or when the food - like avocado - is slippery?
•
Enter stick-shaped pieces of food. Your baby doesn’t need a pincer grasp to hold them, and with practice they direct them to the back corners of their mouths to chew with their gums, where their molars will eventually come in! They can also do this with loaded spoons like the @numnuminc GOOtensils shown here #notsponsored.
•
Serving food this way is not a choking hazard as long as the food is soft. Babies can chew with their back gums far before molars are there. 
•
Of course, you can try a plain wedge/strip of avocado or mashed avocado on a loaded spoon - we just wanted to offer some new ideas too 😍
•
Why do we keep skin on the bottom or roll the avocado in a coating? Avocado can be slippery, especially for new eaters who are learning the amount of pressure they need in their hands to hold foods appropriately. Some coating like fine nutritional yeast or crushed O’s cereal gives it more grip.
•
Avocado is just one awesome food to offer - baby can have most of the foods you’re eating too! Head to our link in bio if you want more help with a gentle, flexible approach to Baby-led Weaning {Infant Self-Feeding} from two feeding professionals. We have been teaching BLW since 2013 😱 and can’t wait to help your family too! 
•
If you’re transitioning from spoon-feeding or are struggling with finger foods, don’t forget to check out the Troubleshooting section of the course!

node.text:
One of the easiest ways to help your picky eater? Put less food on the plate! When they’re visually overwhelmed, they’re less likely to eat. Small amounts of food work wonders for little kids ❤️
•
This also helps when you have a baby who loves to swipe all the food off their tray. Sometimes they get overwhelmed seeing it all and they windshield wipe it away 🙄😫
•
Get more pro tips from the comfort of your home with our self-paced online courses for babies, toddlers and kids - feedinglittles.com.

clips_music_attribution_info.should_mute_audio_reason: Instagram music isn't available in your region.

node.text:
Ahhhh the crap nap 😭 Tell us your secrets for keeping kids awake in the car til you get home 👇👇👇
•
Hopefully at least someone in your house naps today! 😂😂😂

node.text:
UGHHHHH WHY DOES MY TODDLER DROP OR THROW EVERYTHINGGGGG! Psst we talk all about this in our online Toddler/Kid Course, but because we know SO many of you deal with this, here are some tips to get you started 👇👇👇 Tag a friend who might need this! 
•
1. Realize that gravity is a FASCINATING concept for babies and toddlers. “I open my hand and it just…disappears? COOL! And look, it even makes a SOUND when it hits the floor!” Learning about cause and effect is completely normal and natural for them. You’re not the only one dealing with this, TRUST US.
•
2. Make sure you’re eating together. Sometimes kids throw as they seek attention from you, and they know it will get your attention because it’s a maddening behavior. Eat together, making sure your kiddo is right next to the table or seated at the table, and interact during the mealtime if they’re super into throwing.
•
3. When they do throw - IGNORE IT. Don’t react or scold. When they keep their cup, plate or food on the tray, praise them. “Great job keeping your cup here!” Reinforce the behavior you want repeated.
•
4. If they keep dropping their cup, make sure they know where it should go. Make a little “clank” sound as you tap the cup to the tray, or ask them to hand it to you. Repeat it often so they know cup goes here.
•
5. If they keep dropping their food or “clearing the deck,” make sure you only give them a small amount of food at a time. Lots of it can be visually overwhelming and they pitch it overboard. If they don’t want it, show them where they can put it on their plate or tray. Also, many toddlers do this when they’re full. You can ask “Is your tummy full? All done?” and take them out of the chair.
•
6. Some parents find success with their kids cleaning up after they’re done, but make sure this isn’t punitive. “Let’s get the food off the floor. Can you show me where it goes? YES, it goes on your tray!”
•
Friends, this is a PHASE. It will pass - promise! Stay consistent with these tips and know it’s not forever.
•
If you’re dealing with a picky eater, our Toddler/Kid course is for you. We have tons of easy yet profound pro tips that will help your sanity at mealtime - feedinglittles.com 👊

clips_music_attribution_info.should_mute_audio_reason: Instagram music isn't available in your region.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Lunch First day of school: Every other day of school: Y SO LOVE YOu MUCH! Û C bentgokids feedinglittles'.

node.text:
Welp, we’re not that far into the school year and we’re already running out of ideas. Double tap if you relate 😭
•
Don’t fret, friends - we have you covered with some FREE resources! {And don’t worry, they’re nowhere NEAR the fanciness of that first day lunch 😂}
•
1. Our Lunch Toolkit {link in bio} has tons of simple, tasty ideas for building a balanced lunch. It has an easy-to-print chart that will help you come up with new ideas, fast.
•
2. Our “Lunch” highlight is full of real-life lunches Megan packs for her kids, plus ideas on how to keep them cold and safe for lunch time. 
•
There’s absolutely no reason to go overboard and send elaborate lunches if you don’t want to. We simply recommend varying what you send a little bit so your kiddo gets used to seeing variety in their meal. The more variety they see, the more variety they learn to eat in the long run. 
•
What could this look like? 
➡️Today you send sun butter and jelly sandwich on whole grain bread with strawberries, cucumbers and cheese.
➡️Tomorrow you send a cream cheese sandwich on whole grain bread with strawberries, bell peppers and cheese.
•
See? Simple. Check out those resources to get inspired! 

Shown above:
Left - flower cut sandwich with candy center, star-cut cheese, rainbow fruit skewer, candy-coated chocolate, hummus, bell pepper and cucumber.
Right - standard-cut sandwich, blueberries, chocolate, cucumber, cheese.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, food and text that says 'What you assume you'll eat in the first trimester: What you actually eat in the first trimester: feedinglittles'.

node.text:
🍞🥯🥐 Will you tag an expecting or new parent who might relate?
•
Megan here - Registered Dietitian Nutritionist. I’ve worked with hundreds of pregnant people on their nutrition. Some of them breeze through the first trimester without any changes to their nutrition...but many of them really struggle - myself included when I was pregnant.
•
I often hear, “I wish I could eat all my favorite foods, but I can’t stomach the thought of anything except ____{insert starchy food here}.” This is SO common! {And bagels are amazing!} How did you deal with first trimester or all the time nausea, vomiting or food aversions?
•
Here are some tips that helped my clients:
1) Protein for breakfast helps. I know it’s probably the last thing you want to eat, but many pregnant people report an improvement in nausea when they eat protein like eggs, nut/seed butters, cheese etc.
2) Lemon, peppermint and ginger can all help with nausea. Smell sliced lemons {you can keep them in a cup next to you - it’s weird but it works for some} or use lemon or peppermint aromatherapy. Ginger teas and candies can help too - just watch ingredients when using herbal teas. Look for ginger as the only ingredient. Discuss any other herbs with your provider.
3) Consider acupuncture or acupressure - it can lower nausea symptoms significantly in some people.
4) Talk to your provider about taking a B6 supplement {up to 200 mg/day is considered safe for most pregnant people}. Additionally, some find relief from magnesium sprays/supplements.
5) Eat frequent, small meals. Hunger can exacerbate nausea, making it even harder to eat in the long run.
6) Make sure your prenatal vitamin/mineral or any other supplements are taken with food, and make sure that meal {or substantial snack} contains fat to help absorb fat-soluble vitamins. Consider taking it with food before bed. 
7) Lower your expectations. The first trimester, for many pregnancies, is about survival and keeping any food down. Many people can only stomach bread products. Hydration is especially important. If you worry about your nausea/vomiting or nutrition, talk with your provider. Some will require meds or hospitalization for severe nausea/vomiting ❤

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Parenting truths: Your newborn will be suddenly hungry the second you sit down to a hot meal. Constipated baby? Dress them up in a cute outfit and drive somewhere without a change of clothes. Problem solved. You will buy lot of toys, but your kid will be most excited about your cell phone, the remote and sharp objects. The characteristics of your kid that bother you the most are the ones they got from you. Some days you'll count the minutes until bedtime, but you'll miss them while they're sleeping. feedinglittles'.

node.text:
No matter how your baby came to you, parenting is quite the educational experience, eh 😂😘 What are your current parenting truths?
•
Tag a friend who can relate ⬇️⬇️⬇️

node.text:
HOW DARE YOU NOT KNOW THEY WANTED THE BLUE PLATE {today} 😤😤😤🙄🙄🙄 Tag a friend with a toddler at home! ⬇️⬇️⬇️
•
Ahhh isn’t it fun when they become particular about the color of their plate/cup/shirt/EVERYTHING? And when you give their sibling *THEIR* color, the whole world falls apart?!!
•
This is so common as toddlers learn to recognize and identify colors. It’s also really common as kids begin to exert autonomy and independence. They want a sense of control, and sometimes when we unknowingly take it away they freak out.
•
So…how can you manage this fun stage?
•
1. Stick to one color for all your plates, or have one of each color/pattern for each of your kids. EVERYONE GETS PURPLE TONIGHT 👊 
•
2. If they freak out, stay calm. Deep breaths. They’re not doing this to make you angry. They have their own sweet toddler reasons that feel very valid to them. It’s great to validate their frustration and then redirect to give them some autonomy and choice - “Which cup do you want for your water?”
•
3. Know that this is usually temporary. You might go through a blue-plate-only phase, but as they get older they usually get more flexible. If they don’t and it’s seems to get in the way of daily function, talk to your provider. 
•
Need help? Check out our Toddler/Kid Course! Take it at your own pace - it doesn’t expire! Feedinglittles.com 👊

node.text:
And we’ll probably do this for our kids too 😂🤷‍♀️
•
Via @ gold_apparels on Twitter as seen on @barrysbanterbus 💪

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Your job is to let your child not to get your child to eat. feedinglittles'.

node.text:
When we work on letting our child eat versus getting our child to eat, we take away the power struggle ❤️
•
These words were inspired by Jenny McGlothlin’s - @extremepickyeatinghelp - talk at the Responsive Therapy Conference last fall. They’re also a succinct way of describing what we have always taught here and with our clients - when we approach feeding as “getting” our kids to eat, we are not honoring our child’s natural need for independence around food. We are setting ourselves up for more difficulty at the table in the long-run.
•
You see, kids can only control so much in their environment. What they put in their mouth is one of those things. When we force them to eat a certain food or a certain amount, we are telling them that we know more about their body than they do. We are overriding whatever signals they are getting to not eat something. We are breaking down trust they have in themselves and in us as their care provider.
•
As Jenny said in her talk, “Imagine if you went to dinner with a friend who controlled every bite and choice you made as you ate. They made you eat more than you wanted. They told you what to put in your mouth and when. Imagine how you would feel about that eating experience.” Sometimes when we put ourselves in our kids’ shoes, it’s easy to understand why it’s not working for them.
•
Of course, as parents our intent is always good. We want - no, NEED - our kids to grow. We want them to be healthy. We want them to enjoy all different types of food and be a willing participant at mealtime. We are told that it’s our job to get them to grow, eat “healthy,” develop.
•
In our desperation, however, we resort to behaviors that add pressure to our feeding experience:
“Eat three more bites.”
“You have to try your vegetables.”
“No dessert until you eat your food.”
•
Instead, try letting go of control. Let them eat how much they’ll eat and enjoy the food yourself. Talk about their day, not each bite. Enjoy the process. See how it goes - you might be surprised.
•
If you need help with this, please consider our Toddler Course. And if your kiddo has growth, chewing/swallowing or sensory issues, talk to your provider about a feeding consult ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 02, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says 'feedinglittles MYTH: Finger foods for babies must be steamed and served plain. REALITY: Cook your baby's food in the same way you enjoy it- it oils and spices are encouraged. Roast Steam Sauté'.

node.text:
“Do I have to steam everything I give baby?” You can, but you can also cook it how you make it for yourself! Tag a friend feeding a baby right now ❤️😍
•
Many parents assume that they *have* to give babies steamed, plain food. However, babies benefit from different flavors - and cooking oils and spices offer tons of nutrition. We just recommend going easy on the salt, as babies’ kidneys are not as mature as ours and guidance recommends minimizing salt in infancy.
•
What does this mean? Roast, steam, sauté, stir-fry or cook however works for you - what matters is that the food is fork tender or passes the “squish test” (you can squish it between your fingers). Try olive oil, avocado oil, coconut oil or whatever cooking oil you prefer. Dress it up with garlic, cumin, basil, turmeric, black pepper, ginger, whatever you enjoy. Babies can also have spicy flavors and many babies love them - just start small, like with a teeny bit of cayenne pepper.
•
You can also serve the food steamed and plain if that’s how you enjoy it!
•
We recommend offering finger foods as early as 6 months. Our online course guides you through this process with expert tips, checklists and videos. Get access at feedinglittles.com/babies, and feel confident feeding your new eater!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 01, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'Even when you serve these foods regularly... ...it's normal for your child to prefer these: feedinglittles'.

node.text:
YOU ARE NOT A BAD PARENT IF YOUR KID LOVES BEIGE, STARCHY FOODS 🥯🥞🥖 Will you tag a friend feeding a baby, toddler or kid?
•
No food shaming here - please comments kind. Food is food ❤️ It all has nutrition!
•
Foodie Judy here. I’m an Occupational Therapist specializing in feeding therapy with babies and toddlers. No matter how much variety you serve your children, it is still normal for them to prefer crunchy, beige, starchy foods - and cheese.  It doesn’t mean you messed up. It doesn’t mean there’s something wrong with your child. We hope they’ll still eat many other foods, but yes - many kids tend to gravitate toward starches, snacks and anything with cheese.
•
Why do kids prefer these foods?
1) First off, they taste great! When Megan does diet assessments with adults most people report that they love starchy or snack foods {and anything with cheese}. The carb/salt combo is very palatable. There’s nothing shameful about liking the taste of these foods, despite what diet culture tells us.
2) Your toddler may find that a crunchy texture gives them the jaw resistance that teaches their mouths where the food is located. They learn that when they feel this crunch, it feels good inside their mouth, and because of this they learn to seek out crunchy foods more often. For more on why kids prefer crunch from an oral-motor and sensory perspective {and how to utilize their preference to expand what they’ll eat}, click our link in bio.
3) Many kids gravitate toward bread and pasta because they’re easy to chew and have a predictable, mild flavor. Think of how unpredictable very colorful food is - a blueberry can taste sour or sweet. Beige = safe and comfortable.
4) Illness can alter your child’s sense of smell or taste. They may want these foods more when sick 🥰
•
How can you help your kiddo branch out from beige foods?
1) Take our Toddler Course! We walk you through basic feeding therapy techniques in a simple, manageable way!
2) Count any interaction with a new food as a win 💪
3) Serve less familiar toppings, sauces or entrees with a familiar beige starch. 
4) Make sure to check out the post on crunchy foods - there are some great strategies in it! {Link in bio!}
